body:
AP Photo

The Agenda
Megyn talked about Scott, Scott talked about Hillary, and everyone talked about Trump.

            By 
                    The Lazer Lab

While numerous political commentators have offered up their
opinion about who won or lost last week’s GOP debate, we here at the Lazer Lab
at Northeastern University spent the last week looking at the numbers. Actually
we looked at the words: What did candidates actually talk about? How much did
they talk, and for how long? The answers give us three new ways to think about what
mattered in the debate, and who won.
1. It wasn’t all about
Trump, but it was primarily about Trump


The first thing that we noticed was that Trump was clearly the
center of attention. This is reflected in both the number of words he spoke
during the debate, which represents how much of the debate he controlled, and
the number of turns he was given to speak, which shows how often the moderators
gave him control of the floor. Trump uttered almost twice as many words as
debate champion Ted Cruz, or noted filibusterer Rand Paul. He was also the only
candidate to speak more than any of the moderators.


In terms of the number of the number of times they were given
the floor, the moderators gave the most attention to Trump (26 times), Paul
(21), Christie (17) and Bush (11). Trump alone got more than one-fifth of all the
turns to speak. Paul got almost as many turns to speak as Trump (26 vs. 21),
though he said fewer words; this seems to reflect the fact that many of Paul’s
turns to speak came from him aggressively inserting himself in shorter
responses and back-and-forth arguments with other candidates, such as his testy
exchange with Chris Christie.

2. Megyn talked about
Scott. Scott talked about Hillary.


In some ways politics is like the junior-high cafeteria: You
can tell who counts by who gets talked about. So we also looked at who
mentioned whom throughout the debate. All three moderators mentioned Trump by
name more than any of the other candidates on the stage, with Chris Wallace
giving the most attention to Trump. Megyn Kelly mentioned Trump the least of
the moderators—although her interactions were arguably the most
memorable.
The network graph here shows who talked about
whom.
Click for network graph of the GOP debate.
It also reveals that some of the most mentioned figures in the debate
weren’t there at all. A number of candidates mentioned Hillary Clinton, with
Scott Walker mentioning her the most of any of the other candidates. President
Barack Obama was also mentioned a number of times throughout the debate; the
graph shows Cruz, Paul, and Bush all bringing him up.
3. Trump really likes to
talk about Trump
The “word clouds” here are another way to see what candidates
care about. The size of the word indicates the proportion of the time that it
was used, and the first thing we noticed is that Trump was a little different
from the other candidates.
In fact, he was so different that we gave him his own word
cloud. In his word cloud, he takes center stage: his most commonly used words are
“I’m” and “I’ve.” (Other candidates tended to put much more emphasis on
“people.”) Trump used “I” more than three times as often as he used the pronoun
“we”—and no other candidate came close to this ratio. Ted Cruz and Rand Paul
came the closest, using “I” a little less than twice as often as “we.”
Some words in Trump’s word cloud are absent from
those of the other nine candidates—“stupid,” “bankrupt” and “Mexico.” This
does not mean that other candidates didn’t use these words, just that Trump’s
emphasis on them was much higher. These reflect Trump’s
campaign emphasis—securing the border and the stupidity of others—and also the
specific questions leveled by the Fox News moderators about his past business
and political dealings.

How do we define winning?


Some commentators have suggested that Rubio, Carson or even
Fiorina (who participated in the early debate) may have had the best debate
performance. Other commentators have specifically suggested that this debate
may have finally sunk Trump’s campaign. If the goal was to be the center of
attention at the debate, however, Trump clearly achieved it. Primarily because
of the moderators, Trump was able to keep the debate focused on what seems to
be his favorite subject: himself.
Lazer Lab team: David Lazer is Distinguished Professor of Political Science and
Computer and Information Science at Northeastern
University, Visiting Scholar at the
Harvard Kennedy School, and founder of Volunteer
Science. Oren Tsur is a postdoctoral fellow in computational social
science and natural language processing at Northeastern University and Harvard
University. Katherine
Ognyanova is a postdoctoral fellow
in computational social science and network science at  Northeastern
University and Harvard University. Ryan
Kennedy is an associate professor in the department of political science at
the University of Houston.

description: Megyn talked about Scott, Scott talked about Hillary, and everyone talked about Trump.
title: DATA: Trump won the debate — or at least talked the most
